skills.name: Identify equivalent fractions when presented as numbers
Use inequality notation to order fractions whose denominators are multiples of the same number
Use inequality notation to order fractions whose denominators are not multiples of the same number
Represent positive non-unit fractions on a number line

explanations.A: If we shade 3 out of 3 pieces, we are shading the whole shape. 3/3 make one whole, which is 1.
explanations.B: Not quite - 3 is three whole ones. If we shade 3/3 parts of this shape, how many whole ones have we shaded?
explanations.C: Not quite - if we shade 3/3 parts of this shape, how many whole ones have we shaded?
explanations.D: We can write this fraction as a whole number. If we shade 3/3 parts of this shape, how many whole ones have we shaded?

explanations.A: Not quite - if we shade 4/4 parts of this shape, how many whole ones have we shaded?
explanations.B: If we shade 4 out of 4 pieces, we are shading the whole shape. 4/4 make one whole, which is 1.
explanations.C: Not quite - 4 is four whole ones. If we shade 4/4 parts of this shape, how many whole ones have we shaded?
explanations.D: We can write this fraction as a whole number. If we shade 4/4 parts of this shape, how many whole ones have we shaded?

explanations.A: This line is split into 4 parts, so each part is 1/4. Where would we find 4/4?
explanations.B: Careful, I think you counted as if the first mark is 1/4, but the scale starts at 0. 4/4 would be four jumps along from 0.
explanations.C: The scale is split into 4 parts so each jump along from 0 is 1/4. 4/4 is 4 jumps after 0, which gets us to C. 4/4 is also equal to one whole, so it's at 1 on the scale.
explanations.D: Picture shading 4/4 (four quarters) of a circle. Is that bigger than one whole one? Each jump along this scale is 1/4, so count 4 jumps along.

explanations.A: This line is split into 5 parts, so each part is 1/5. Where would we find 5/5?
explanations.B: Careful, I think you counted as if the first mark is 1/5, but the scale starts at 0. 5/5 would be five jumps along from 0.
explanations.C: The scale is split into 5 parts so each jump along from 0 is 1/5. 5/5 is 5 jumps after 0, which gets us to C. 5/5 is also equal to one whole, so it's at 1 on the scale.
explanations.D: Picture shading 5/5 (five fifths) of a circle. Is that bigger than one whole one? Each jump along this scale is 1/5, so count 5 jumps along.

explanations.A: Picture shading 7/7 (seven sevenths) of a circle. Is that the same as shading 7 whole circles?
explanations.B: If we have 7 out of 7 parts, we have one whole one.
explanations.C: Picture shading 7/7 (seven sevenths) of a circle. How many whole circles is that?
explanations.D: Picture shading 7/7 (seven sevenths) of a circle. How many whole circles is that?

explanations.A: Picture shading 6/6 (six sixths) of a circle. How many whole circles is that?
explanations.B: Picture shading 6/6 (six sixths) of a circle. How many whole circles is that?
explanations.C: If we have 6 out of 6 parts, we have one whole one.
explanations.D: Picture shading 6/6 (six sixths) of a circle. How many whole circles is that?

explanations.A: Picture shading 10/10 (ten tenths) of a circle. Is that less than the whole circle?
explanations.B: Picture shading 10/10 (ten tenths) of a circle. Is that more than the whole circle?
explanations.C: If we have 10 out of 10 parts, we have one whole one. Therefore they are equal!
explanations.D: Picture shading 10/10 (ten tenths) of a circle. Is it less than, more than or equal to one whole circle?

explanations.A: Picture shading 11/11 (eleven elevenths) of a circle. Is that less than the whole circle?
explanations.B: Picture shading 11/11 (eleven elevenths) of a circle. Is that more than the whole circle?
explanations.C: If we have 11 out of 11 parts, we have one whole one. Therefore they are equal!
explanations.D: Picture shading 11/11 (eleven elevenths) of a circle. Is it less than, more than or equal to one whole circle?

explanations.A: Picture shading 7/7 (seven sevenths) of a circle. Now picture shading 2/2 (two halves) of a circle. Can you compare them now?
explanations.B: 7 is more than 2, but picture shading 7/7 (seven sevenths) of a circle. Now picture shading 2/2 (two halves) of a circle. Can you compare them now?
explanations.C: Picture shading 7/7 (seven sevenths) of a circle. Now picture shading 2/2 (two halves) of a circle. Both fractions are equal to one whole one, so they are equal to each other.
explanations.D: Picture shading 7/7 (seven sevenths) of a circle. Now picture shading 2/2 (two halves) of a circle. Can you compare them now?

explanations.A: Picture shading 5/5 (five fifths) of a circle. Now picture shading 1/1 (one whole) of a circle. Can you compare them now?
explanations.B: 5 is more than 1, but picture shading 5/5 (five fifths) of a circle. Now picture shading 1/1 (one whole) of a circle. Can you compare them now?
explanations.C: Picture shading 5/5 (five fifths) of a circle. Now picture shading 1/1 (one whole) of a circle. Both fractions are equal to one whole one, so they are equal to each other.
explanations.D: Picture shading 5/5 (five fifths) of a circle. Now picture shading 1/1 (one whole) of a circle. Can you compare them now?
